integrations_researched.name: Pygame
gotchas: Must call pygame.init() before using any pygame functions
Event loop must run continuously to keep window responsive
Colors specified as RGB tuples (0-255 each)
Text rendering requires font initialization each time
pros: Full control over rendering and input
Common choice for 2D games in Python
Easy to handle mouse events (left/right click)
cons: More boilerplate than Tkinter for simple GUIs

integrations_researched.name: Tkinter

verified_package.name: tkinter
verified_package.install_command: No installation needed - included in Python standard library

imports: from tkinter import Button, Frame, Label

gotchas: Main loop must be started with root.mainloop()
Layout management: grid() vs pack() vs place() - grid() best for Minesweeper
Default styling looks dated (but can be customized)
Right-click may need special handling on macOS
Event handlers receive event object with position info
pros: No external dependencies - built into Python
Native look and feel on each platform
Ideal for Minesweeper's grid of clickable cells
cons: Default appearance looks like classic Windows 95 (could be pro or con)
Less suitable for complex animations or effects

gameplay: Grid of clickable cells with hidden mines
Blank cells (0) auto-reveal adjacent cells (flood fill)
Chording: When number of flags equals cell number, clicking reveals all adjacent non-flagged cells
Game over if mine is clicked
Win when all non-mine cells are revealed
ui_elements: Reset button (face icon that reacts to game state)
Menu bar with Game, Help options
Difficulty selection: Beginner, Intermediate, Expert, Custom
advanced_features: Question marks (optional feature - could flag with ? to mark uncertain)
High score tracking (fastest times per difficulty)
Keyboard shortcuts: F2 for new game

recommendations: **For closest Windows Minesweeper replica**: Use Tkinter - its native button widgets provide classic Minesweeper look and feel with minimal code.
**For modernized/cross-platform polish**: Use Pygame - allows custom rendering, smoother animations, and consistent appearance across platforms.
**Tkinter advantages for this project**: Built into Python (no setup), perfect for grid-based games, handles left/right-click natively, matches original Minesweeper's UI paradigm.
**Pygame advantages**: More flexibility for custom graphics, better performance if adding visual effects, more modern game development patterns.
**Critical features to implement**: (1) Flood-fill algorithm for blank cells, (2) Right-click flagging, (3) Mine counter and timer, (4) Chording mechanic, (5) All three standard difficulty levels.

algorithm_requirements: Flood fill (DFS or BFS) for revealing blank cells and adjacent non-mine cells
Random mine placement with first-click safety guarantee
Chording: reveal neighbors when flags === cell number
data_structure: 2D array or list of lists for the board
Each cell needs: mine status (bool), revealed status (bool), flagged status (bool), adjacent_mine_count (int 0-8)
state_management: Timer: start on first click, stop on game end
